author: sky.cactus
content: I wouldn't put much stake in the predictions of a company that needs to pitch to investors.

author: sky.cactus
content: I would estimate that the time required to migrate away from ECDSA is on the order of a year if there was sufficient pressure to do so, so as long as there is ~1 year notice of breaking elliptic curve cryptography there would be time to adjust.  That being said, as always I feel like the right solution is a new blockchain that people can *voluntarily* migrate to at their leisure.

author: norwayfish
content: But how exactly do we migrate away from ECDSA? Everyone's public key is forever in the history? You can't simply update the nodes to use a new algo for the same key pair, you literally need a mechanism to move funds from one key to another?

author: norwayfish
content: If that's the case, then this should be offered and forced to be done by every user like today? Are we just betting that everyone will migrate 'quickly enough' (when it's offered), otherwise you lose your funds?

author: norwayfish
content: and even then our only bet is lattice based PKE

author: sky.cactus
content: One could imagine a migration from one key type to another, and once you migrate the old keytype cannot be used anymore.

author: norwayfish
content: but this requires the user to explicitly use their key to transfer all of their funds from all of their accounts to new accounts before a certain deadline

author: norwayfish
content: how do you even announce to everyone that this needs to be done and as soon as possible

author: sky.cactus
content: It is certainly a hard problem!  I would also like to see account abstraction focused on sooner rather than later, which would allow users to use other cryptographic primitives.

author: sky.cactus
content: However, I am a bit hesitant to say that this is a problem that needs to be solved *immediately* just because one company claims that quantum computers are soon (especially since they have incentive for people to believe this).

author: tersec
content: One challenge is that one cannot simply specify "a new algo", one has to specify which new algorithm. There are leading contenders, but it's also a relatively immature space, where even competent cryptographers are submitting algorithms which get (by usual cryptography standards) quickly/catastrophically broken: https://arstechnica.com/information-technology/2022/08/sike-once-a-post-quantum-encryption-contender-is-koed-in-nist-smackdown/

author: tersec
content: Or Rainbow, another post-quantum candidate, https://eprint.iacr.org/2022/214 was also broken (and not just in the "it takes 2^120 time rather than 2^128 time", but "Breaking Rainbow Takes a Weekend on a Laptop")
